Award.AwardTitle: Transport Properties of Self-Assembled DNA Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Summary
Practical nanotechnology requires precise and inexpensive placement of nanometer-size components into an operational unit. The DNA nanotechnology achieves exactly that by utilizing the self-assembly property of DNA. This project will explore the use of self-assembled DNA materials for controlling the motion of molecules through fluid environment. Computer simulations will elucidate the mechanism of electrical conductivity of self-assembled DNA structures. Nanoscale objects will be designed to function as analogs of electrical wires, pipes and transistors. Mimicking nature, membrane-spanning DNA systems will be developed to regulate the passage of biomolecules across a cell boundary. These research activities will be closely integrated with education and outreach and will provide the rapidly expanding field of DNA nanotechnology with computational methods and tools for theoretical exploration of self-assembled DNA structures.

Technical Summary
This project aims to characterize the transport properties of self-assembled DNA nanostructures for possible applications in biosensing, nanofluidics, and biomimetic systems. All-atom molecular dynamics simulations will characterize the ionic conductivity of various DNA origami designs and probe their structural integrity in an external electric field. The simulations will explore the behavior of DNA gridirons and DNA bricks structures, and evaluate their usefulness for nanopore sensing applications. Charged and hollow DNA origami constructs will be designed to serve as conduits for ions and small biomolecules in fluid environment, analogous to macroscopic wires and pipes. The structural response of the DNA origami to electric field will be exploited to design and demonstrate a DNA origami transistor. The physical principles of gated and selective biological ion channels will be implemented in membrane-spanning DNA constructs. The theoretical work will be carried out in close collaboration with experimentalists characterizing the transport through self-assembled DNA structures. This project is expected to provide new insights into the physical mechanisms of charged solutes transport in fluid environment, finding practical application in nanopore detection of biomolecules, unconventional computing and synthetic tissue engineering.
This research program will have a direct impact on the development of functional DNA nanotechnology by providing the research community with methods and tools to build, visualize and simulate self-assembled DNA systems. The technological knowledge and expertise acquired through this program will be made available through step-by-step tutorials, modules of the popular computer program VMD and as research and educational tools at nanoHUB. Material generated within this project will be used to prepare a set of lectures and demos for the biophysics undergraduate and graduate courses. The project will develop educational DNA origami puzzles and a DNA LEGO constructor kit and will make them available to everyone by taking advantage of the 3D printing technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-assembly of DNA molecules into complex three-dimensional objects has emerged as a new paradigm for arranging matter at the nanoscale. The exquisite control over the properties of nanoscale objects offered by DNA self-assembly has potential applications in a broad range of scientific disciplines and emergent technologies, from massively parallel fabrication of miniature devices to drug delivery systems that recognize and selectively treat diseased cells. This project has explored the potential use of self-assembled DNA systems as elements of novel electrical circuits, as sensors of biological information, as miniature channels that transport signals and nutrients in and out of a biological cell and as artificial enzymes that alter the composition of cell membranes. Undertaking these studies required development of computational methods and tools that could predict the behavior of DNA objects in solution. Models of self-assembled DNA structures have been developed at multiple scales ranging from single atoms to macroscopic objects and validated through close collaboration with experimental laboratories. The project’s products have been closely integrated with educational and outreach activities, providing the rapidly expanding field of DNA nanotechnology with computational methods and tools and introducing the general public to exciting developments in the field.

Intellectual merit. This project has pushed the frontier of the design of self-assembled nanosystems by developing a portfolio of computational methods and tools to accurately predict the systems’ structural and transport properties. Starting from a computational study of single objects—plates and rods—the project characterized the mechanical properties of DNA nanomaterials, finding them to be both compliant with external deformation and leaky to water and ions. These very properties, however, were essential to design a miniature voltage sensor that could transcribe electric field-dependent deformation of the structure into light signal. Further computer simulations revealed that placement of DNA nanostructures in cell membranes offers several pathways for water, ions and nutrients to pass from one side of the membrane to the other. First, the molecules could permeate through a hollow channel carved by design within the nanostructure. In addition to that, the very interactions between DNA and molecules of the cell membrane alter the membrane’s structure, opening additional permeation pathways in the space between the DNA nanostructure and the membrane. The latter effect—the perforation of the cell membrane—was found to be able to dramatically change the membrane composition, facilitating the scrambling of molecules residing at the inner and outer sides of the membrane. Such scrambling, which DNA nanostructures are found to perform thousands of times more efficiently than naturally occurring biological machines, has opened new opportunities to the treatment of diseases caused by deficient scrambling and targeting cancer cells for destruction.

Broader impact. This research program has contributed to the application of concepts of biological self-organization in science and engineering. The novel class of miniature devices developed through this program may find applications in a range of different fields, most notably, in sensing biological information and affecting behavior of biological cells, including development of cancer therapeutics. The technological knowledge and expertise acquired through this program has been made available to a broad scientific community through numerous presentations at national and international meetings, step-by-step tutorials, design conversion tools, structure prediction webservers, and integrative workflows available online. Hundreds of researchers have been trained face-to-face in hands-on workshops and summer schools. In collaboration with the teachers from Illinois high schools, research outcomes of this project have been transformed into educational material. Interactive demonstrations and hands-on activities have been designed to engage elementary and middle school students and their families. Scientific discoveries were disseminated to the general public through lectures, news stories and media highlights. The students supported by this program are now continuing their career development at top US research institutions and companies.

Modified by: Aleksei Aksimentiev

Models of self-assembled DNA structures have been developed at multiple scales ranging from single atoms to macroscopic objects and validated through close collaboration with experimental laboratories.
